case_title: JAI KISHAN SRIVASTAVA vs INCOME-TAX OFFICER, KANPUR, AND ANOTHER

key_points.issue_1: Validity of Section 34(1-A) under Article 14 of the Constitution.
key_points.issue_2: Bias of Income-tax Officer in judicial or quasi-judicial proceedings.
key_points.decision_on_issue_1: Section 34(1-A) does not violate Article 14 as the procedure and rights under the Act are identical to Section 34(1).
key_points.decision_on_issue_2: Income-tax Officer's role does not violate principles of natural justice due to appellate mechanisms available.

facts.initial_notices: May 17, 1948, under Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947
facts.subsequent_notices: December 29, 1954, under Section 34(1-A) of the Income-tax Act

petitioner: Income-tax Officer has bias as a party in proceedings.
respondent: Section 34(1-A) applies equally and does not deny rights.
Income-tax Officer acts within statutory duties without bias.

judgment_summary.interpretation_of_section_34(1-A): Provisions of the Act apply to proceedings under Section 34(1-A), including appeals and references.
judgment_summary.principles_of_natural_justice: Income-tax Officer's decisions are valid due to appellate safeguards.
judgment_summary.discrimination_claim: Section 34(1-A) does not create unconstitutional discrimination.
